item.title: entropy
item.description: For a given phase space, Hamiltonian and energy, entropy quantifies the number of micro-states available. Details In the Gibbs (canonical) ensemble (NVT), the partition function reads $$ Z = \sum_i e^{-\beta E_i} $$an with the probability of the micro-state $i$ being $p_i=e^{-\beta E_i} / Z$, we have $$ S_G=-k_B \sum_i p_i \log(p_i) $$

item.title: Schrödinger's code-script aperiodic crystal
item.description: In 1944, Schrödinger imagine that a “code-script” could be found in “aperiodic crystals” (chromosomes) of living systems ( Schrödinger, 1944). Without mentionning “information”, it does refer to a discrete encoding and therefore implies Laplacian determinism (and predictability).

item.title: second principe of thermodynamic
item.description: The [[entropy]] of a closed system with fixed volume can only increase. It is maximum at equilibrium for a system at constant energy.

item.title: Shannon's theory of information transmission
item.description: Be $X$ a random variable with $X\in{x_1,x_2,…,x_n}$ and $p_i=\mathbb{P}(X=x_i)$. Shannon relates the amount of information of one string to the amount of surprise of seeing it.

item.title: Turing machine
item.description: In 1936, Turing introduces the idea of a “computing machine”, latter called “Turing machine”. He pictures not a mecanism but a person — “Turing’s architect” according to ( Schrodinger1944) Turing introduced ( Turing1936) this machine trying to answer questions regarding decidability.

item.title: abacus
item.description: An abacus is a “higher-level” (more flexible) [[concept/Turing machine]] for computation. Every abacus-computable function is Turing computable. All [[definition/recursive function]]s are abacus-computable.

item.title: Cantor's diagonal argument
item.description: One of Cantor’s theorem is that the set of all sets of natural numbers is not enumerable. The set of real numbers is the set of all set of natural numbers because you form a real number by precising its decimals.

item.title: Church-Turing thesis
item.description: An [[definition/arithmetic function]] is [[definition/effectively computable]] if and only if it is computable by a [[concept/Turing machine]] (or — using the [[definition/computable]] equivalence — if it is is a [[definition/recursive function]]).

item.title: computable
item.description: Three notions of computability are equivalent: The existence of a Turing machine computing the function. The abacus-computability. A recursive function A function is computable on a Turing machine if and only if it is a recursive function

item.title: enumerable set
item.description: A set is enumerable if and only if it is the range of some [[definition/arithmetic function]]. (The range is the set of the function’s values.

item.title: halting problem
item.description: Given a [[concept/Turing machine]] and an initial binary strings, the problem consists in knowing if it will halt or not. This problem cannot be solve on a [[concept/Turing machine]] because the halting function is [[definition/uncomputable]].

item.title: recursive function
item.description: It refers to functions that can be built with the zero, the successor and the identity function by use of composition, minimization and primitive recursion: $$h(x,0)=f(x), \ h(x,y’)=g(x,y,h(x,y))$$ They are all [[definition/effectively computable]].

item.title: uncomputable
item.description: Due to Cantor’s diagonal argument, we know that the set of arithmetic functions that have a range on positive integers is not an enumerable set.
